elements.content: Employing a flexible phosphoramide ligand L, PhPO­(NH3Py)2 (3Py = 3-pyridyl), four new Cu­(II) cationic coordination assemblies 1, 1a, 2, and 3 of composition {[Cu2L4(H2O)2]·(ClO4)4·(H2O)5·(CH3OH)}∞, {[Cu3L6(H2O)3]·(ClO4)5·(NO3)·(H2O)11}∞, {[Cu4L8(H2O)5]·(NO3)8·L·(H2O)9}, and {[Cu3L6]·(NO3)6·(H2O)8·(CH3OH)2}, respectively, were synthesized. The compounds 1 and 1a having perchlorate and mixed perchlorate-nitrate anions, respectively, were obtained as noncentrosymmetric 1D-helical assemblies. However, 2 and 3 were obtained as discrete centrosymmetric assemblies of composition M4L8 and M3L6, respectively. Interestingly, 2 can encapsulate the hydrated potassium cation [K­(H2O)8]+ in its intrinsic cavity. The ferroelectric measurements of 1 and 1a gave a well saturated ferroelectric hysteresis loop giving saturation polarization (P s) values of 1.8 and 0.55 μC/cm2, respectively. This indicates that the presence of nitrate anion in the packing structure has an effect in altering the asymmetry of the system, which causes a change of polarization in 1a in comparison with that of 1. Furthermore, the room temperature dielectric constant values of 118.7, 27.4, and 39.2 for 1, 1a, and 2, respectively, suggest that they are potential candidates for high-technique applications.

Furthermore, the room temperature dielectric constant values of 118.7, 27.4, and 39.2 for 1, 1a, and 2, respectively, suggest that they are potential candidates for high-technique applications.

elements.content: Over the past decades, coordination driven self-assemblies of metal–ligand ensembles have taken a crucial place in the domain of supramolecular chemistry due to their facile synthesis and novel applications. The simplicity and the spontaneity of self-assembly methods allow the design of novel structural architectures ranging from one-dimensional helices to two-dimensional grids and sheets as well as three-dimensional frameworks and polyhedra. Several studies have demonstrated that these self-assemblies exhibit interesting structure dependent physical properties such as electric, magnetic, and nonlinear optical properties. Materials that exhibit ferroelectric properties are very important due to their utility in nonvolatile computing devices, capacitors, and signaling devices. Ferroelectric substances with high permittivity (dielectric constant) values are important in the development of dielectric resonators and microwave telecommunication signal processing units. Traditionally, ceramic and inorganic oxide materials have been employed for these purposes. Currently, organic and organic–inorganic hybrid materials are vastly explored as ferroelectric materials for their efficiency and flexibility in device fabrication. In this effort, self-assembled metal organic hybrids have gained attention owing to their ready syntheses and tunable properties. However, syntheses of self-assembled ferroelectric materials are still challenging because of the strict requirement of a helical and noncentrosymmetric polar packing arrangement of the molecular constituents. Several factors, viz., coordination geometry around the metal ion, nature of the ligand, the role of counteranions, and solvent systems, have been found to contribute toward noncentrosymmetric, chiral, or polar lattice parameters. Although it is difficult to measure the role of each of these factors, a careful choice of the metal ions and counteranions in combination with a nonrigid ligand system can contribute to polar noncentrosymmetric crystal parameters which could eventually give rise to ferroelectric self-assemblies. To test this hypothesis, we set out to synthesize both centrosymmetric and noncentrosymmetric structural motifs for the same metal–ligand combination depending upon the reaction conditions and counteranions. For this, a simple and flexible P–N ligand (L), featuring neutral pyridyl N-donor sites, was treated with Cu­(II) ions (a labile metal ion) in the presence of perchlorate/nitrate anions (Scheme ). These reactions yielded four new cationic coordination assemblies, of the type {[CuL2] n [A]2n } (1, n = ∞, A = (ClO4 –); 1a, n = ∞, A = (ClO4 –)0.835 + (NO3 –)0.165; 2, n = 4, A = (NO3 –); and 3, n = 3, A = (NO3 –)), in three unique structures. While compounds 1 and 1a display a noncentrosymmetric 1D-helical chain structure, compounds 2 and 3 were obtained as centrosymmetric discrete assemblies. Permittivity measurements on 1, 1a, and 2 show high dielectric constant values for all of them. Further, 1 and 1a were shown to exhibit ferroelectric behavior at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past decades, coordination driven self-assemblies of metal-ligand ensembles have taken a crucial place in the domain of supramolecular chemistry due to their facile synthesis and novel applications. The simplicity and the spontaneity of self-assembly methods allow the design of novel structural architectures ranging from one-dimensional helices to two-dimensional grids and sheets as well as three-dimensional frameworks and polyhedra. Several studies have demonstrated that these self-assemblies exhibit interesting structure dependent physical properties such as electric, magnetic, and nonlinear optical properties. Materials that exhibit ferroelectric properties are very important due to their utility in nonvolatile computing devices, capacitors, and signaling devices. Ferroelectric substances with high permittivity (dielectric constant) values are important in the development of dielectric resonators and microwave telecommunication signal processing units. Traditionally, ceramic and inorganic oxide materials have been employed for these purposes. Currently, organic and organic-inorganic hybrid materials are vastly explored as ferroelectric materials for their efficiency and flexibility in device fabrication. In this effort, self-assembled metal organic hybrids have gained attention owing to their ready syntheses and tunable properties. However, syntheses of self-assembled ferroelectric materials are still challenging because of the strict requirement of a helical and noncentrosymmetric polar packing arrangement of the molecular constituents. Several factors, viz., coordination geometry around the metal ion, nature of the ligand, the role of counteranions, and solvent systems, have been found to contribute toward noncentrosymmetric, chiral, or polar lattice parameters. Although it is difficult to measure the role of each of these factors, a careful choice of the metal ions and counteranions in combination with a nonrigid ligand system can contribute to polar noncentrosymmetric crystal parameters which could eventually give rise to ferroelectric self-assemblies. To test this hypothesis, we set out to synthesize both centrosymmetric and noncentrosymmetric structural motifs for the same metal-ligand combination depending upon the reaction conditions and counteranions. For this, a simple and flexible P-N ligand (L), featuring neutral pyridyl N-donor sites, was treated with Cu(II) ions (a labile metal ion) in the presence of perchlorate/nitrate anions (Scheme ). These reactions yielded four new cationic coordination assemblies, of the type {[CuL2] n [A]2n } (1, n = ∞, A = (ClO4 -); 1a, n = ∞, A = (ClO4 -)0.835 + (NO3 -)0.165; 2, n = 4, A = (NO3 -); and 3, n = 3, A = (NO3 -)), in three unique structures. While compounds 1 and 1a display a noncentrosymmetric 1D-helical chain structure, compounds 2 and 3 were obtained as centrosymmetric discrete assemblies. Permittivity measurements on 1, 1a, and 2 show high dielectric constant values for all of them. Further, 1 and 1a were shown to exhibit ferroelectric behavior at room temperature.

elements.content: All manipulations involving phosphorus halides were performed under dry nitrogen atmosphere in standard Schlenk-glassware. The solvent toluene was dried over sodium. 3-Aminopyridine was purchased from Aldrich and used as received. PhPOCl2 was purchased from Acros-Organics and used as received. Tetrabutylammonium nitrate and copper perchlorate salts were purchased from Aldrich, and Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O and KNO3 were purchased from Merck and used as received. NMR spectra were recorded on a Jeol 400 MHz spectrometer (1H NMR, 400.13 MHz; 13C­{1H}­NMR, 100.62 MHz; 31P­{1H} NMR, 161.97 MHz) at room temperature using SiMe4 (1H, 13C) and 85% H3PO4 (31P). The MALDI-TOF spectra were obtained on an Applied Biosystem MALDI-TOF/TOF spectrometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were obtained from a Bruker-D8 Advance diffractometer. Thermal analysis (TGA) data have been obtained from a PerkinElmer STA-6000 thermogravimetric analyzer. DC-magnetic measurements were obtained from Quantum Design MPMSXL magnetic properties measurements system. An electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrum was obtained on a Jeol, Japan JES -FA200 ESR spectrometer with X-band frequency. Elemental analyses were performed on a Vario-EL cube elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were taken on a PerkinElmer spectrophotometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. Melting points were obtained using an Electro thermal melting point apparatus and were uncorrected.

Experimental Section

General Remarks

All manipulations involving phosphorus halides were performed under dry nitrogen atmosphere in standard Schlenk-glassware. The solvent toluene was dried over sodium. 3-Aminopyridine was purchased from Aldrich and used as received. PhPOCl2 was purchased from Acros-Organics and used as received. Tetrabutylammonium nitrate and copper perchlorate salts were purchased from Aldrich, and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O and KNO3 were purchased from Merck and used as received. NMR spectra were recorded on a Jeol 400 MHz spectrometer (1H NMR, 400.13 MHz; 13C{1H}NMR, 100.62 MHz; 31P{1H} NMR, 161.97 MHz) at room temperature using SiMe4 (1H, 13C) and 85% H3PO4 (31P). The MALDI-TOF spectra were obtained on an Applied Biosystem MALDI-TOF/TOF spectrometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were obtained from a Bruker-D8 Advance diffractometer. Thermal analysis (TGA) data have been obtained from a PerkinElmer STA-6000 thermogravimetric analyzer. DC-magnetic measurements were obtained from Quantum Design MPMSXL magnetic properties measurements system. An electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrum was obtained on a Jeol, Japan JES -FA200 ESR spectrometer with X-band frequency. Elemental analyses were performed on a Vario-EL cube elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were taken on a PerkinElmer spectrophotometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. Melting points were obtained using an Electro thermal melting point apparatus and were uncorrected.

elements.content: L: To a stirred solution of 3-aminopyridine (11.756 g, 125 mmol) in toluene (∼200 mL) at 0 °C, PhPOCl2 (2.5 mL, 3.475 g, 17.82 mmol) in 10 mL of toluene was added dropwise through a pressure equalizer funnel under inert atmosphere, and the reaction mixture was refluxed for 4 h. The residue was filtered and washed 3–4 times with distilled water to get a white solid, which was then dried and collected. Colorless crystalline needles suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) analysis were obtained from its methanolic solution after 2 days. Yield: 4.92 g (89%). M.P.: 223–225 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, (CD3)2SO: δ 2.05 (s, 2H, NH), 7.16 (d, 2H, CH), 7.52 (dt, 4H, CH), 7.82 (td, 2H, CH), 8.01 (s, 2H, CH), 8.35 (td, 4H, CH). 31P NMR (161 MHz, {(CD3)2SO}): δ 10.04. FT-IR data in KBr pellet (cm–1): 3464, 1587, 1477, 1386, 1197, 1120, 1061, 938, 810, 699, and 514. ESI-MS= 311 (M+H)+. Anal. Calcd for C16H15N4OP: C, 61.93; H, 4.87; N, 18.06. Found: C, 62.01; H, 4.84; N, 17.97.

elements.content: 1: To a stirred solution of L (62 mg, 0.2 mmol) in MeOH (3 mL), Cu­(ClO4)2·6H2O (37 mg, 0.1 mmol) in H2O (3 mL) was added. To this mixture, 5 drops of DMF was added, and the stirring was continued for 4 h. The solution was then filtered through a thick pad of Celite and left for crystallization. Large blue crystals of 1 suitable for SCXRD analysis were obtained after 2–3 weeks. Yield: 53% (51 mg), based on Cu. FT-IR data in the KBr pellet (cm–1): 3440, 1607, 1584, 1499, 1391, 1335, 1275, 1194, 1120, 1087, 946, 809, 696, 624, and 521. MALDI-TOF: m/z = 311 (L + H)+, 683 (CuL2)+. Anal. Calcd for C65H78N16O28P4Cu2Cl4: C, 40.57; H, 4.09; N, 11.65. Found: C, 40.43; H, 4.11; N, 11.52.

elements.content: Reflections were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex Duo diffractometer at 100 K using MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for L, 1, 1a, 2a, 3, and 2⊃[K­(H2O)8]. For 2, the data was collected on a Bruker D8 Venture fitted with a microfocus detector at 150 K using CuKα radiation ((λ = 1.54178 Å). Structures were refined by full-matrix least-squares against F2 using all data (SHELX). Crystallographic data for all of these compounds are listed in Table S1 (). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined aniostropically if not stated otherwise. Hydrogen atoms were constrained in geometric positions to their parent atoms. Crystals of L, 1, and 3 were weakly diffracting at higher angles, and hence, a 2θ = 50° cutoff was applied. Four perchlorate ions in 1 and one perchlorate ion in 1a were disordered. Similarly some of the nitrate ions, phenyl rings, and phosphoryl oxygen atoms in 2, 2a, 2⊃[K­(H2O)8], and 3 were thermally disordered. Atom positions of the disordered groups were freely refined isotropically over two positions using similar distances and similar U-restraints. Some of the nitrate ions in these structures were disordered along with the solvate water molecules. Hence, these were treated as diffuse contributions to the overall scattering and removed by the SQUEEZE/PLATON for a better refinement data. The exact amount of the solvate water molecules were further confirmed by TGA data. The refinement parameters in 2 and 2a were slightly higher owing to the diffuse nature of these highly solvated crystals as well as to a large number of unique atoms in the asymmetric unit.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

Reflections were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex Duo diffractometer at 100 K using MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for L, 1, 1a, 2a, 3, and 2⊃[K(H2O)8]. For 2, the data was collected on a Bruker D8 Venture fitted with a microfocus detector at 150 K using CuKα radiation ((λ = 1.54178 Å). Structures were refined by full-matrix least-squares against F2 using all data (SHELX). Crystallographic data for all of these compounds are listed in Table S1 (). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined aniostropically if not stated otherwise. Hydrogen atoms were constrained in geometric positions to their parent atoms. Crystals of L, 1, and 3 were weakly diffracting at higher angles, and hence, a 2θ = 50° cutoff was applied. Four perchlorate ions in 1 and one perchlorate ion in 1a were disordered. Similarly some of the nitrate ions, phenyl rings, and phosphoryl oxygen atoms in 2, 2a, 2⊃[K(H2O)8], and 3 were thermally disordered. Atom positions of the disordered groups were freely refined isotropically over two positions using similar distances and similar U-restraints. Some of the nitrate ions in these structures were disordered along with the solvate water molecules. Hence, these were treated as diffuse contributions to the overall scattering and removed by the SQUEEZE/PLATON for a better refinement data. The exact amount of the solvate water molecules were further confirmed by TGA data. The refinement parameters in 2 and 2a were slightly higher owing to the diffuse nature of these highly solvated crystals as well as to a large number of unique atoms in the asymmetric unit.

elements.content: In order to determine the dielectric and ferroelectric properties, the powdered samples of these compounds were compacted in the form of discs (of approximately 10 mm diameter and 1 mm thickness). The compacted discs were subsequently attached to aluminum adhesive foils which act as electrodes for both ferroelectric and dielectric measurements. The frequency dependent dielectric characteristics for 1, 1a, and 2 at various temperatures were measured using the Novocontrol dielectric spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Ferroelectric and Dielectric Measurements

In order to determine the dielectric and ferroelectric properties, the powdered samples of these compounds were compacted in the form of discs (of approximately 10 mm diameter and 1 mm thickness). The compacted discs were subsequently attached to aluminum adhesive foils which act as electrodes for both ferroelectric and dielectric measurements. The frequency dependent dielectric characteristics for 1, 1a, and 2 at various temperatures were measured using the Novocontrol dielectric spectrometer.

elements.content: The ferroelectric hysteresis loop in 1 and 1a were measured by using a Sawyer-Tower circuit. Both polarizations and fatigue studies were recorded using a hysteresis loop analyzer (TF Analyzer 2000, aixACCT Germany). Time dependent leakage current was measured dynamically during the hysteresis loop measurements. It was recorded for various applied voltage steps using the TF analyzer. The P–E loop results show that remnant polarization in the positive direction is slightly lower than that in the negative direction for the sample 1, and a reverse of this trend was observed in the case of 1a. The asymmetries of the hysteresis loop in the two opposite directions can be related to the electrode asymmetry (adhesive aluminum foils), which is attributed to the variations in the air gap between the electrode and the sample at the top and bottom surfaces. The asymmetric reversal of the loop in sample 1a in comparison with that in 1 is due to the switch in electric field direction and different leakage currents under a positive and negative bias. The gap observed at the start and end points of the P–E hysteresis is due to the delay period between the (i) preset loop and the start of the measurement loop, (ii) space charge formed from the lattice distortion, and (iii) energy traps at the electrode interfaces.

elements.content: The precursor ligand L was synthesized from PhPOCl2 and excess 3-aminopyridine in refluxing toluene (Figures S1, S2, S10, and S11, ). The 1D-helical assembly of 1 was isolated as blue crystals in a 2:1 reaction mixture involving L and Cu­(ClO4)2 in MeOH/H2O medium at room temperature. Conversely, treatment of L with Cu­(NO3)2 gave the Cu4L8 cavitand complex 2 (an uncoordinated free ligand was found in its packing cavity). In order to obtain the helical assembly of 1 with only nitrate anions, L was treated with Cu­(ClO4)2 and ( n Bu4N)­NO3 in 2:1:1 ratio. However, the obtained blue crystals indicated the formation of 1a with mixed perchlorate/nitrate combination. In another attempt, treatment of 1 with excess ( n Bu4N)­NO3 in methanol gave a new discrete trinuclear M3L6 complex 3 in low yields along with the quantitatively precipitated sample of 1a admixed with unreacted ( n Bu4N)­NO3. In order to see whether 3 can be obtained in a direct reaction, we treated L with Cu­(NO3)2 and ( n Bu4N)­NO3 in methanol (Scheme ). However, the obtained crystals showed the formation of the same tetranuclear Cu4L8 assembly 2a, {[Cu4L8(H2O)5]·(NO3)8·(H2O)9}, with a slightly different packing composition, instead of 3. The MALDI-TOF mass spectra of all these compounds gave a prominent peak at m/z = 683 corresponding to the [CuIIL2] moiety suggesting that all these assemblies are built from the same set of repeating units (Figures S3–S8, ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

The precursor ligand L was synthesized from PhPOCl2 and excess 3-aminopyridine in refluxing toluene (Figures S1, S2, S10, and S11, ). The 1D-helical assembly of 1 was isolated as blue crystals in a 2:1 reaction mixture involving L and Cu(ClO4)2 in MeOH/H2O medium at room temperature. Conversely, treatment of L with Cu(NO3)2 gave the Cu4L8 cavitand complex 2 (an uncoordinated free ligand was found in its packing cavity). In order to obtain the helical assembly of 1 with only nitrate anions, L was treated with Cu(ClO4)2 and ( n Bu4N)NO3 in 2:1:1 ratio. However, the obtained blue crystals indicated the formation of 1a with mixed perchlorate/nitrate combination. In another attempt, treatment of 1 with excess ( n Bu4N)NO3 in methanol gave a new discrete trinuclear M3L6 complex 3 in low yields along with the quantitatively precipitated sample of 1a admixed with unreacted ( n Bu4N)NO3. In order to see whether 3 can be obtained in a direct reaction, we treated L with Cu(NO3)2 and ( n Bu4N)NO3 in methanol (Scheme ). However, the obtained crystals showed the formation of the same tetranuclear Cu4L8 assembly 2a, {[Cu4L8(H2O)5]⋅(NO3)8⋅(H2O)9}, with a slightly different packing composition, instead of 3. The MALDI-TOF mass spectra of all these compounds gave a prominent peak at m/z = 683 corresponding to the [CuIIL2] moiety suggesting that all these assemblies are built from the same set of repeating units (Figures S3-S8, ).

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Diagram Showing the Anion Driven Assemblies of the [CuIIL2]n Frameworks

elements.content: The molecular structures (Table S1, ) of all these assemblies consists of [CuIIL2] n (1, n = ∞; 1a, n = ∞; 2, n = 4; and 3, n = 3) repeat units having corner-shared 20-membered Cu2L2 macrocycles. The coordination environment at the Cu­(II) centers in all of them contains four equatorial Npyridyl sites and an apical coordination from either water molecules (1, 1a, 2, and 2a) or nitrate ions (3). Thus, the coordination geometry in all of these assemblies can best be described as distorted square pyramidal (sp) except for one of the four Cu­(II) atoms in 2 and 2a which exhibits an octahedral coordination with two axial water molecules. The molecular structures of 1 and 1a were solved in the trigonal noncentric polar space group R 3 (polar point group of C 3). The repeating unit of the helical assembly of 1 consists of two Cu­(II) ions, four ligand motifs, and two coordinated water molecules on each Cu­(II) atom. The charge balance is restored by the presence of four perchlorate ions. The molecular structure can be viewed as a left-handed helical double chain consisting of an infinite array of Cu2L2 macrocyclic segments (Figure a). The two coordinated Npyridyl sites of the ligand are mutually positioned to give an arrangement that is in between the syn and anti conformations with respect to the PO groups. Every fourth macrocyclic segment is in the replicating position of the first one contributing to an approximate 120° rotation. Each ligand motif within the Cu2L2 segments could be considered as part of a distinct chain which upon propagation gives rise to two fused left-handed strands (Figure c). The pitch of the helical chains was found to be around 25.5 Å, and the width of the helix is approximately 10 Å. The packing diagram of the molecule shows the presence of trigonal channel structures (Figure b) which are occupied by the disordered perchlorate ions and solvate molecules. The cationic assembly in 1a resembles to that of 1 with closely related metric parameters (Table S2, ) except that the asymmetric unit in 1a consists of one-half of the segments found in 1 (Figure S12, ).

elements.content: The crystal structures of 2 and 2a were solved in the monoclinic centrosymmetric space group P2 1 /n. The molecular core in both of them consists of a tetranuclear cationic Cu4L8 rectangular-cavitand with the approximate point group symmetry of D 4 (Figure a–c). The cavitand structure in 2 can be viewed as a planar array of four Cu­(II) atoms which are connected by four bidentate ligand pairs above and below the Cu4 plane. Thus, the Cu4L8 moiety consists of four Cu2L2 segments similar to those found in 1. The charge balance is restored by the presence of eight nitrate anions. Further, two coordinated Npyridyl sites of the ligands in 2 are mutually positioned in syn conformations with the PO groups pointing inward in an endo orientation. The cationic ensemble in 2 (and in 2a) can be viewed as a metal–ligand analogue of cucurbiturils (CBs) consisting of symmetrical apertures at the top and bottom ends, except that the M-H2O groups in 2 are located inside the cavity (in the case of CBs, the hydroxyl groups are located above and below the internal cavity). The cavity diameters in 2 (and 2a) are measured to be at approximately 6.5 and 8.1 Å, and the outer dimensions are in the range between CB[6] and CB[8] (Figure d and Figure S15a–b, ). The contact surface volume of the cavity is approximately 153 Å3 as calculated by the mercury software. The intrinsic pores in 2 and 2a were filled with disordered solvate water molecules (Figure S13, ).

elements.content: The crystal structure of 3 was solved in the monoclinic centrosymmetric space group P2 1 /c. The asymmetric unit consists of one and a half Cu­(II) ions, three ligand motifs, three nitrate ions located over four positions with two of them coordinated (with Cu­(II) ions) and two of them uncoordinated, two methanol molecules, and four H2O molecules. The molecular core consists of a cationic M3L6 cage-like framework (D3 symmetry) having three corner-shared Cu2L2 segments (Figure a and b). The Cu2 atom is located on a mirror plane, and hence, the nitrate ion attached to it is positionally disordered on either side of the plane. The formation of the discrete cage assembly of 3 from 1 can be envisioned via the cleavage of two of the six Cu–N bonds at either ends of the helical turn followed by the ring closure at the terminal metal sites. In 3, the angle between the two Cu-centers was nearly 60° to give an overall angle of 179.97° (58.52, 58.52, and 62.96°). Whereas, in 1 the twist angle between the three successive Cu-centers is approximately 155°. Moreover, the two coordinated Npyridyl sites of the ligands in 3 are oriented in syn conformation with respect to the PO groups as observed for 2 and 2a. As computed from MSROLL software calculations, the intrinsic void space in 3 was found to be 65 Å3 with a fixed probe radius of 1.4 Å. Further, the cavity was found to be occupied by 4.25 disordered water molecules over five positions in trigonal bipyramidal geometry (Figure c).

elements.content: Gas adsorption studies performed on the activated sample of 2 (and 2a) did not show any appreciable uptake characteristics for CO2 and N2. This could be attributed to the hindered access for the gas molecules in the intrinsic cavity of 2 caused by its solid-state packing structure (Figure S14, ). Nevertheless, the cavity dimensions in 2 are suitable for the host–guest chemistry in solution. Thus, the reaction of 2 with excess KNO3 in water/methanol gave the complex {[(Cu4L8(H2O)4)⊃(K­(H2O)8)]·(NO3)9·(H2O)9}, which encapsulated the K+ ion in the hydrated form (2⊃[K­(H2O)8]) (Figure ). The molecular structure of 2⊃[K­(H2O)8] shows that the tetrameric structure of 2 was retained in the solid state with marginal changes in its inner diameters ranging from 6.2 to 9.2 Å caused by the guest encapsulation (Figure S15c, ). The coordination geometry around the K+ ion in its primary hydration sphere can be described as distorted dodecahedral. The four coordinated molecules on each Cu2+ ion and the phosphoryl oxygen atoms provide the second sphere coordination to the encapsulated K+ ion. However, similar attempts with NaNO3 and CsF did not result in any guest encapsulation exemplifying that the cavity space in 2 is specific only for the hydrated K+ ion.
elements.clean_text:
Guest-Encapsulation Studies of 2 

Gas adsorption studies performed on the activated sample of 2 (and 2a) did not show any appreciable uptake characteristics for CO2 and N2. This could be attributed to the hindered access for the gas molecules in the intrinsic cavity of 2 caused by its solid-state packing structure (Figure S14, ). Nevertheless, the cavity dimensions in 2 are suitable for the host-guest chemistry in solution. Thus, the reaction of 2 with excess KNO3 in water/methanol gave the complex {[(Cu4L8(H2O)4)⊃(K(H2O)8)]⋅(NO3)9⋅(H2O)9}, which encapsulated the K+ ion in the hydrated form (2⊃[K(H2O)8]) (Figure ). The molecular structure of 2⊃[K(H2O)8] shows that the tetrameric structure of 2 was retained in the solid state with marginal changes in its inner diameters ranging from 6.2 to 9.2 Å caused by the guest encapsulation (Figure S15c, ). The coordination geometry around the K+ ion in its primary hydration sphere can be described as distorted dodecahedral. The four coordinated molecules on each Cu2+ ion and the phosphoryl oxygen atoms provide the second sphere coordination to the encapsulated K+ ion. However, similar attempts with NaNO3 and CsF did not result in any guest encapsulation exemplifying that the cavity space in 2 is specific only for the hydrated K+ ion.

elements.content: As 1 and 1a belong to one of the 10 polar point groups (C1, Cs, C2, C2v, C3, C3v, C4, C4v, C6, and C6v) that are associated with ferroelectric behavior, the ferroelectric measurements were performed on their samples. A well saturated polarization (P) vs electric field (E) hysteresis loop was obtained for both 1 and 1a at room temperature, confirming the occurrence of ferroelectricity in them (Figure ). Further, the extremely low leakage (10–5 to 10–6 A) currents demonstrate that observed hysteresis loops are clearly due to ferroelectricity. The saturated polarization (P s) value of 1 is seen to be 1.8 μC/cm2, which is higher than that of Rochelle salt (0.25 μC/cm2) and several recently reported metal organic materials, and slightly smaller than that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate (5 μC/cm2). Whereas, a lower P s value of 0.55 μC/cm2 has been observed for 1a. The coercive field (E c) of 1 and 1a equals about 16 kVcm–1 and 30 kVcm–1, respectively, which are smaller than those of several polymeric ferroelectrics. However, the saturation polarization and the rectangularity of the loop decreases for both 1 and 1a with increase in frequency. Preliminary ferroelectric fatigue studies on these compounds show that the remnant polarization (P r) remains unchanged after several switching operations. This confirms the presence of switchable ferroelectric domains in them even after several cycles.
elements.clean_text:
Ferroelectric and Dielectric Studies

As 1 and 1a belong to one of the 10 polar point groups (C1, Cs, C2, C2v, C3, C3v, C4, C4v, C6, and C6v) that are associated with ferroelectric behavior, the ferroelectric measurements were performed on their samples. A well saturated polarization (P) vs electric field (E) hysteresis loop was obtained for both 1 and 1a at room temperature, confirming the occurrence of ferroelectricity in them (Figure ). Further, the extremely low leakage (10-5 to 10-6 A) currents demonstrate that observed hysteresis loops are clearly due to ferroelectricity. The saturated polarization (P s) value of 1 is seen to be 1.8 μC/cm2, which is higher than that of Rochelle salt (0.25 μC/cm2) and several recently reported metal organic materials, and slightly smaller than that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate (5 μC/cm2). Whereas, a lower P s value of 0.55 μC/cm2 has been observed for 1a. The coercive field (E c) of 1 and 1a equals about 16 kVcm-1 and 30 kVcm-1, respectively, which are smaller than those of several polymeric ferroelectrics. However, the saturation polarization and the rectangularity of the loop decreases for both 1 and 1a with increase in frequency. Preliminary ferroelectric fatigue studies on these compounds show that the remnant polarization (P r) remains unchanged after several switching operations. This confirms the presence of switchable ferroelectric domains in them even after several cycles.

elements.content: As observed with most ferroelectric materials, the polarization in 1 and 1a originates from the spatial asymmetry of these cationic helical assemblies, in addition to the contributions from the polarizable free counteranions (ClO4 –/NO3 –). Further, the anion induced polarization in them originates from two distinct kinds of guest (anions and solvents) arrangements found in the trigonal channels present in their unit-cell packing (Figure S16, ). The high saturation polarization and rectangularity obtained for 1 is primarily attributed to its nonpolar packing arrangements. Thus, the addition of nitrate ion has an effect in altering the asymmetry of the system, which causes a change of polarization in 1a. This is evidenced by the higher coercive field (30 kVcm–1) that is required for its ferroelectric switching operations. Moreover, the electrical fatigue is reduced to 104 cycles in 1a in comparison with 105 cycles in 1. Such a behavior is normally attributed to decrease in polarizability of the system, movement of space charges (similar to n-p hopping charges and oxygen vacancies observed in metal-oxides), and the orientation of switchable ferroelectric domains.

elements.content: Furthermore, studies on behavior of the real part of the dielectric constant and the dielectric loss factor as a function of frequency at various temperatures on 1, 1a, and 2 were performed (Figure ). The room temperature dielectric constant values at 1 Hz for 1, 1a, and 2 are 118.7, 27.4, and 39.2, respectively, suggesting them as high dielectric constant materials. The ferroelectric nature of sample 1 is evident from its large dielectric constant (∼120) at room temperature. The observed decrease in dielectric constant in 1a is again due to the distortions in nonpolar arrangements causing a break in the long-range interactions within the helical assembly. In fact, it is interesting to observe a significant dielectric constant for 2 despite its centrosymmetric nature. Also as observed from Figure , all of these three materials show very low dielectric loss factors.

elements.content: As with most dielectric materials, the dielectric constant of all of these three compounds increases with increase in temperature and decrease in frequency (Figure and Figures S17–S19, ). The increasing trend of dielectric constant with decrease in frequency is due to the contribution of all of the polarization (space-charge, orientation, ionic, and electronic) mechanisms at lower frequencies (<100 Hz). As frequency increases, space charge, ionic, and electronic polarizations become inoperative in that order. The same behavioral trend has also been observed in many ferroelectric materials. The increase in dielectric constant with temperature is due to the increase in dominance of interfacial polarization compared to dipolar polarization.
elements.clean_text: As with most dielectric materials, the dielectric constant of all of these three compounds increases with increase in temperature and decrease in frequency (Figure  and Figures S17-S19, ). The increasing trend of dielectric constant with decrease in frequency is due to the contribution of all of the polarization (space-charge, orientation, ionic, and electronic) mechanisms at lower frequencies (<100 Hz). As frequency increases, space charge, ionic, and electronic polarizations become inoperative in that order. The same behavioral trend has also been observed in many ferroelectric materials. The increase in dielectric constant with temperature is due to the increase in dominance of interfacial polarization compared to dipolar polarization.

elements.content: In conclusion, the present work shows that counteranions such as perchlorate or nitrate ions can not only control the structural architectures in the same metal–ligand combination but also alter the physical properties associated with them. Thus, the iso-structural 1D-helical assemblies of 1 and 1a exhibit large variations for ferroelectric saturation polarization (P s) and dielectric constant values as the higher values are observed for the former one. Also, the tetrameric cavitand 2 shows a significant dielectric constant despite having a centrosymmetric structure. In addition, the hydrophilic nature of the central cavity in 2 was confirmed by the encapsulation of a hydrated potassium cation. Similarly, 3 can host a water cluster in its intrinsic cavity. These results demonstrate that anion driven self-assembly is a facile approach for tuning the behavior of metal–organic ferroelectrics and pave the way for the synthesis of new practical materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, the present work shows that counteranions such as perchlorate or nitrate ions can not only control the structural architectures in the same metal-ligand combination but also alter the physical properties associated with them. Thus, the iso-structural 1D-helical assemblies of 1 and 1a exhibit large variations for ferroelectric saturation polarization (P s) and dielectric constant values as the higher values are observed for the former one. Also, the tetrameric cavitand 2 shows a significant dielectric constant despite having a centrosymmetric structure. In addition, the hydrophilic nature of the central cavity in 2 was confirmed by the encapsulation of a hydrated potassium cation. Similarly, 3 can host a water cluster in its intrinsic cavity. These results demonstrate that anion driven self-assembly is a facile approach for tuning the behavior of metal-organic ferroelectrics and pave the way for the synthesis of new practical materials.

L: To a stirred solution of 3-aminopyridine (11.756 g, 125 mmol) in toluene (∼200 mL) at 0 °C, PhPOCl2 (2.5 mL, 3.475 g, 17.82 mmol) in 10 mL of toluene was added dropwise through a pressure equalizer funnel under inert atmosphere, and the reaction mixture was refluxed for 4 h. The residue was filtered and washed 3–4 times with distilled water to get a white solid, which was then dried and collected. Colorless crystalline needles suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) analysis were obtained from its methanolic solution after 2 days. Yield: 4.92 g (89%). M.P.: 223–225 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, (CD3)2SO: δ 2.05 (s, 2H, NH), 7.16 (d, 2H, CH), 7.52 (dt, 4H, CH), 7.82 (td, 2H, CH), 8.01 (s, 2H, CH), 8.35 (td, 4H, CH). 31P NMR (161 MHz, {(CD3)2SO}): δ 10.04. FT-IR data in KBr pellet (cm–1): 3464, 1587, 1477, 1386, 1197, 1120, 1061, 938, 810, 699, and 514. ESI-MS= 311 (M+H)+. Anal. Calcd for C16H15N4OP: C, 61.93; H, 4.87; N, 18.06. Found: C, 62.01; H, 4.84; N, 17.97.

1: To a stirred solution of L (62 mg, 0.2 mmol) in MeOH (3 mL), Cu­(ClO4)2·6H2O (37 mg, 0.1 mmol) in H2O (3 mL) was added. To this mixture, 5 drops of DMF was added, and the stirring was continued for 4 h. The solution was then filtered through a thick pad of Celite and left for crystallization. Large blue crystals of 1 suitable for SCXRD analysis were obtained after 2–3 weeks. Yield: 53% (51 mg), based on Cu. FT-IR data in the KBr pellet (cm–1): 3440, 1607, 1584, 1499, 1391, 1335, 1275, 1194, 1120, 1087, 946, 809, 696, 624, and 521. MALDI-TOF: m/z = 311 (L + H)+, 683 (CuL2)+. Anal. Calcd for C65H78N16O28P4Cu2Cl4: C, 40.57; H, 4.09; N, 11.65. Found: C, 40.43; H, 4.11; N, 11.52.

1a: To a stirred solution of L (62 mg, 0.2 mmol) in MeOH (3 mL), a solution of Cu­(ClO4)2·6H2O (37 mg, 0.1 mmol) and tetrabutylammonium nitrate [{(C4H9)4N}­NO3] (30 mg, 0.1 mmol) in H2O (3 mL) was added. To this mixture, 5 drops of DMF was added, and the stirring was continued for another 4 h. The solution was then filtered through a thick pad of Celite and left for crystallization. Blue crystals of 1a suitable for SCXRD analysis were obtained after 2–3 weeks. Yield: 57% (54 mg), based on Cu. FT-IR data in KBr pellet (cm–1): 3489, 1608, 1584, 1499, 1390, 1336, 1275, 1194, 1121, 1092, 942, 808, 696, 622 and 521. MALDI-TOF: m/z = 311 (L + H)+, 683 (CuL2)+. Anal. Calcd for C96H118N25O43P6Cu3Cl5: C, 40.26; H, 4.15; N, 12.23. Found: C, 40.12; H, 4.03; N, 12.12.

2: To a stirred solution of L (62 mg, 0.2 mmol) in MeOH (3 mL), Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (24 mg, 0.1 mmol) in H2O (3 mL) was added, and the stirring was continued for another 4 h. The solution was then filtered through a thick pad of Celite and left for crystallization. Blue crystals of 2 suitable for SCXRD analysis were obtained after 2 weeks. Yield: 61% (52 mg), based on Cu. FT-IR data in KBr pellet (cm–1): 3474, 1607, 1584, 1503, 1478, 1384, 1273, 1192, 1121, 1064, 1028, 943, 807, 695, 623, 521 and 503. MALDI-TOF: m/z = 311 (L + H)+, 683 (CuL2)+. Anal. Calcd for C144H163N44O47P9Cu4: C, 45.57; H, 4.33; N, 16.24. Found: C, 45.38; H, 4.22; N, 16.09.

2a: To a stirred solution of L (62 mg, 0.2 mmol) in MeOH (3 mL), a solution of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (24 mg, 0.1 mmol) and tetrabutylammonium nitrate [{(C4H9)4N}­NO3] (100 mg, 0.3 mmol) in H2O (3 mL) was added, and the stirring was continued for a another 4 h. The solution was then filtered through a thick pad of Celite and left for crystallization. Large blue crystals of 2a suitable for SCXRD analysis were obtained after 3–4 weeks. Yield: 58% (50 mg), based on Cu. FT-IR data in KBr pellet (cm–1): 3454, 1608, 1584, 1502, 1479, 1385, 1272, 1191, 1122, 1064, 1028, 947, 809, 690, 652, and 509. MALDI-TOF: m/z = 311 (L + H)+, 683 (CuL2)+. Anal. Calcd for C128H148N40O46P8Cu4: C, 44.12; H, 4.28; N, 16.08. Found: C, 43.96; H, 4.17; N, 16.20.

2⊃[K­(H2O)8]: (a) To a solution of KNO3 (101 mg, 1 mmol) in methanol and water (10 mL), crystals of 2 (20 mg) were added and stirred for 24 h. The solution was then filtered through a thick pad of Celite and left for crystallization. Rectangular rod-like blue crystals of 2⊃[K­(H2O)8] suitable for SCXRD analysis were obtained after a week. Yield: 43% (8.4 mg), based on Cu. (b) To a stirred solution of L (62 mg, 0.2 mmol) in MeOH (5 mL), Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (24 mg, 0.1 mmol) and KNO3 (50 mg, 0.5 mmol) in H2O (3 mL) were added and stirred further. The solution was then filtered through a thick pad of Celite and left for crystallization. Rectangular rod-like blue crystals of 2⊃[K­(H2O)8] suitable for SCXRD analysis were obtained after a week. Yield: 49% (43 mg), based on Cu. FT-IR data in KBr pellet (cm–1): 3484, 3144, 3060, 1607, 1584, 1503, 1479, 1384, 1272, 1192, 1122, 1064, 1028, 942, 807, 695, 521, and 503. MALDI-TOF: m/z = 311 (L + H+), 683 (CuL2 +). Anal. Calcd for C128H162N41O56P8Cu4: C, 41.42; H, 4.40; N, 15.47. Found: C, 41.55; H, 4.48; N, 15.60.

3: To the solution of tetrabutylammonium nitrate [{(C4H9)4N}­NO3] (100 mg, 0.33 mmol) in MeOH (10 mL), crushed crystals of 1 (20 mg, 0.01 mmol) was added with slow stirring. After 4–5 h, formation of a greenish-blue precipitate was observed. The slow stirring was continued for 48 h, and then the solution was filtered, and the filtrate was kept at RT for crystallization. Blue crystals of 3 suitable for analysis by SCXRD technique were obtained after a week. Yield: 4% (3.5 mg), based on Cu. FT-IR data in KBr pellet (cm–1): 3450, 1597, 1460, 1384, 1299, 1269, 1152, 1054, 926, 771, 644, 587, 498, and 483. MALDI-TOF: m/z = 311 (L + H+), 683 (CuL2)+. Anal. Calcd for C98H114N30O34P6Cu3: C, 44.69; H, 4.32; N, 15.42. Found: C, 44.52; H, 4.24; N, 15.57.
